clean_content:
Definition / general

* Pancreatic well differentiated neuroendocrine tumor that causes clinical symptoms secondary to secretion of gastrin

Essential features

* Functionally active and usually aggressive neuroendocrine tumor* Gastrin secretion causes Zollinger-Ellison syndrome* May occur sporadically or in the setting of MEN1

Terminology

* Pathology diagnosis should be well differentiated neuroendocrine tumor, as gastrinoma is a clinical determination* Sometimes called G cell neoplasm

ICD coding

* ICD-O: [8153/3](https://apps.who.int/iris/bitstream/handle/10665/96612/9789241548496_eng.pdf?sequence=1#page=66) - gastrinoma, malignant* ICD-10: [C25.4](https://www.icd10data.com/ICD10CM/Codes/C00-D49/C15-C26/C25-/C25.4) - malignant neoplasm of endocrine pancreas

Epidemiology

* Roughly 20% of functional pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors are gastrinomas, though only about 5% of overall pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors are gastrinomas ([Surg Pathol Clin 2014;7:559](26837555), [World J Gastroenterol 2006;12:5440](17006979))

Sites

* Gastrinomas are more common in duodenum than in pancreas* Rare examples of so called primary lymph node gastrinoma can occur:
    + Gastrin producing tumors in lymph nodes with no GI or pancreatic primary, generally in patients with MEN1 ([Am J Surg Pathol 2008;32:1101](18520436))+ Occur in gastrinoma triangle: from cystic and common bile ducts to the second and third portion of the duodenum to neck and body of the pancreas+ May be due to gastrin secreting neuroendocrine cells within these nodes or due to occult duodenal microgastrinomas with lymph node metastasis ([Arch Pathol Lab Med 2000;124:832](10835515), [Am J Surg Pathol 2008;32:1101](18520436))

Pathophysiology / etiology

* Hypersecretion of gastrin stimulates secretion of gastric acid by parietal cells, leading to ulcer formation

Etiology

* 80% of cases are sporadic; 20% are familial due to MEN1 ([Hepatogastroenterology 2005;52:1668](16334754))

Clinical features

* Associated with hypersecretion of gastric acid and severe peptic ulceration* 90% have ulcers (85% in duodenum / jejunum, 15% in stomach)* 33% of patients have diarrhea* May be metastatic at time of diagnosis

Diagnosis

* Glucagon provocative test is useful ([Surg Today 2013;43:1281](22983734))

Radiology description

* Highly vascular and well circumscribed, as with other neuroendocrine tumors of pancreas* Imaging may detect positive lymph nodes within the gastrinoma triangle ([Diagn Interv Imaging 2016;97:1241](27876341))* Octreotide scans have high sensitivity

Radiology images

Images hosted on other servers:  

[![Missing Image](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/thumb/pancreasgastrinomalh3ggpht01.jpg)](https://lh3.ggpht.com/-_6NBN2T_D3U/UtHgwYWIIjI/AAAAAAAAOY8/omrgPbZO5q4/s1600-h/image1.png)

CT of pancreatic gastrinoma

Prognostic factors

* Sporadic tumors are usually solitary, aggressive and located in pancreas* MEN1 cases are often multicentric, less aggressive and arise in duodenal wall ([Gut 2007;56:606](17440178))

Case reports

* 25 year old woman with mass blocking the pancreatic duct ([Surgery 2005;138:111](16003327))* 37 year old woman with von Hippel-Lindau syndrome and 2 pancreas lesions ([Rev Esp Enferm Dig 2017;109:154](27055912))* 68 year old woman with abdominal pain and diarrhea ([Oncol Lett 2016;11:3433](27123130))* 73 year old man with pancreatic gastrinoma and endobronchial metastasis ([Am J Respir Crit Care Med 2012;185:590](22383575))

Treatment

* H2 blockers for symptom management* Surgical resection of tumor

Gross description

* Single or multiple lesions, most commonly in head of pancreas* Firm, homogeneous, well circumscribed

Gross images

AFIP images  

[![Missing Image](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/pancreasgastrinomaAFIPgross1.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/pancreasgastrinomaAFIPgross1.jpg)

Lymph node gastrinoma

Microscopic (histologic) description

* Nests of monotonous low grade neuroendocrine cells with salt and pepper nuclei and ample amphophilic cytoplasm, as with any other well differentiated neuroendocrine tumor* Associated with pancreatic polypeptide cell hyperplasia ([Hum Pathol 1997;28:149](9023394))* Nonneoplastic pancreas may show large islets and [nesidioblastosis](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/pancreasnesidio.html)

Microscopic (histologic) images

Contributed by Raul S. Gonzalez, M.D. and AFIP images  

[![](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/pancreasgastrinomagonzalez01new.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/pancreasgastrinomagonzalez01new.jpg)
 
[![](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/pancreasgastrinomagonzalez02new.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/pancreasgastrinomagonzalez02new.jpg)

Nests and cords of cells

[![](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/pancreasgastrinomaAFIPmicro1.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/pancreasgastrinomaAFIPmicro1.jpg)

Malignant tumor has trabecular pattern

[![](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/pancreasgastrinomaAFIPmicro2.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/pancreasgastrinomaAFIPmicro2.jpg)

Lobular trabecular pattern

Positive stains

* [Gastrin](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainsgastrin.html) (though this does not establish the diagnosis)* [Synaptophysin](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainssynaptophysin.html), [chromogranin](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainschromogranin.html)* **PDX1**, [INSM1](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainsinsm1.html) ([Am J Surg Pathol 2012;36:737](22498824))

Negative stains

* [CK7](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainsck7.html) (8%) ([Am J Surg Pathol 2012;36:737](22498824))* [CDX2](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainscdx2.html)* [BCL10](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainsbcl10.html) ([Pathol Int 2013;63:176](23530562))* Nuclear [beta catenin](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainsbetacatenin.html) ([World J Gastrointest Onc 2016;8:615](27574554))

Electron microscopy description

* Tumor cells may contain small, electron dense granules

Electron microscopy images

AFIP images  

[![](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/pancreasgastrinomaAFIPEMI1.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/pancreasgastrinomaAFIPEMI1.jpg)

Pancreatic gastrinoma

Sample pathology report

* Pancreas and duodenum, Whipple procedure:
  + Pancreatic neuroendocrine tumor, WHO grade 2 (see synoptic report and comment)+ Comment: The patient’s clinical history of Zollinger-Ellison syndrome is noted. This may be due to gastrin secretion by this tumor, which would make it a gastrinoma. Immunohistochemical stains for synaptophysin and chromogranin are positive and the Ki67 index is approximately 4.5%.

Differential diagnosis

* **Nongastrin secreting [pancreatic neuroendocrine tumor](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/pancreaspen.html)**:
  + No histopathologic differences+ Must be determined on clinical grounds
